author: S Prasad
text:
AINRC Legislator P. Angalane, who had recently switched his loyalty to the Congress without resigning his MLA post, has the proverbial Damocles sword hanging on his head and much depends on whether the Assembly Speaker invokes the provisions of the Anti-defection Law.

Political observers point out that Puducherry has always been presenting a murky political picture with most of the elected MLAs acting on their own and raising a banner of revolt against the party leadership on several occasions.

Elected Legislators shifting their loyalties to other political parties have virtually been a rule rather than an exception in the Union Territory of Puducherry.

The first instance of defection reported in the UT after the Anti-defection Law came into force was in 1987 when the AIADMK MLAs Dr. M.A.S. Subramanian and K. Anbalagan switched their loyalty from the AIADMK to the DMK.

In 1990, two MLAs – P. Rajavelu and Devinayagam belonging to the Janata Dal were disqualified after they defected to the Samajwadi Party. However, the then Speaker G. Perumalraja restored the membership of the two MLAs within hours of disqualification in the Assembly.

The third instance of defection was in 2000 when M. Manjini elected from the Mudaliarpet Assembly constituency on a CPI ticket shifted his allegiance to the PMK.

Mr. Manjini was immediately disqualified under the Tenth Schedule to the Constitution of India.

Legislators shifting their loyalties have been a rule rather than an exception in Puducherry
title: Angalane’s MLA post: ball in Speaker’s court
